AbstractTickLabelFormatter

public AbstractTickLabelFormatter(java.lang.String s)
Method Detail

getMaxDimensionDummyTick

public double getMaxDimensionDummyTick(Layer layer,
                                       GssProperties axisProperties)
Return a dummy string whose font metrics will bound any possible value returned from formatFullTick

formatFullTick

public java.lang.String formatFullTick(double domainPoint)
Return a fully qualified date, for example, if your ticks are years, then the date would be '2007', if they are months, 'Nov'07', and if they are days, '13 Nov'07'

formatRelativeTick

public java.lang.String formatRelativeTick(double domainPoint)
Return a relative date, which assumes that a nearby fullTick is being rendered to give the user a visual context. For example, if rendering a month, then a relative tick label would be 'Nov', and if day, a relative day would be '13'.

getInterval

public double getInterval()
The size of the interval represented by getMaxTicks, in seconds. For example, an Hour formatter will return 86,400,000, the number of seconds in a day.

getMaxTicks

public int getMaxTicks(double start,
                       double end)
Return the max number of divisions per interval for this formatter. For example, if it is an Hour tick formatter, then this will return 24. if months, it will return 12.

getMinTicksBeforeSubInterval

public int getMinTicksBeforeSubInterval()
How many ticks must capable of being rendered on the screen before this formatter should be used. (i.e. if the user has zoomed out so much that only 2 divisions can be squeezed on the screen, and this formatter says you must have 4, then the subinterval will not be rendered.

getSubIntervalFormatter

public org.timepedia.chronoscope.junit.render.TickLabelFormatter getSubIntervalFormatter()
Return the next zoom level of labels

getSuperIntervalFormatter

public org.timepedia.chronoscope.junit.render.TickLabelFormatter getSuperIntervalFormatter()
Return the previous zoom level of labels

getTick

public double getTick(double origin,
                      double intervalEnd,
                      int tickNum,
                      int numTicks,
                      int maxTicks)
Return the domain position of a tick, given the origin, and end interval, the maximize number of ticks begining rendered, the number that will be rendered, and the tick number beging requested.

For example, a day has 24 hours. The given interval between (origin, intervalEnd) may not be able to squeeze 24 tick labels in the screen space alotted. Therefore, numTicks will represent how many can actually fit in the given domain interval, say 4 ticks. tickNum will range from 0 to 3 then, representing 00:00, 06:00, 12:00, and 18:00.

inInterval

public boolean inInterval(double domainStart,
                          double domainEnd)
Is this domain interval best represented by this tick formatter?

quantizeTicks

public int quantizeTicks(double ticks)
Quantize the number of ticks you propose to render to a value which is more aesthetically pleasing, typically a divisor of the max number of ticks. Thus, for 12 months, it means you render either no ticks, 2 ticks, 3 ticks, 4 ticks, 6 ticks, or 12 ticks.

quantizeToNearest

public double quantizeToNearest(double dO)
Quantize a domain value to the nearest tick. For example, quantizing to year will return values which begin on January 1, 00:00:00, and quantizing to month will return a value which begins on the first day of the month.
